(cousin, deceased) }} '''Hakimullah Mehsud''' ([[Pashto language|Pashto]]/{{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|حکیم اللہ محسود}}}}{{lrm}}; c. 1979 − 1 November 2013), born '''Jamshed Mehsud''' ({{lang|ur|{{Nastaliq|جمشید محسود}}}}{{lrm}}) and also known as '''Zulfiqar Mehsud''' ({{lang|ur|{{Nastaliq|ذو الفقار محسود}}}}), was the [[emir]] of [[Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan]] (TTP).{{cite news|title=Profile: Hakimullah Mehsud |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8219223.stm|work=BBC News| date=25 August 2009|accessdate=5 January 2010}}{{cite news|author1=Kahn, Ismail |author2=Polgreen, Linda|title=New leader of Pakistan's Taliban is named, though officials believe he is dead |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/23/world/asia/23pstan.html|date=22 August 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=22 August 2009}}{{cite news|last1=Rodriguez |first1=Alex |last2=Ali |first2=Zulfiqar|title=Pakistani Taliban names new leader |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-taliban-leader23-2009aug23,0,7080329.story |date=22 August 2009|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=22 August 2009}} He was deputy to commander [[Baitullah Mehsud]] and one of the leaders of the militant group [[Fedayeen al-Islam]] prior to the elder Mehsud's death in a [[Drone attacks in Pakistan|CIA drone missile strike]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/news/1904884-pakistan-hakimullah |title=Hakimullah Mehsud unveils himself to media |publisher=All Voices |date=29 November 2008 |accessdate=9 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103193533/http://www.allvoices.com/news/1904884-pakistan-hakimullah |archivedate=3 November 2013 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/asia/displayStory.cfm?story_id=13446862|title=Pakistan's extremists: The slide downhill|date=8 April 2009|work=The Economist|accessdate=28 May 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/news/world/pakistan/Baitullahs-likely-successor-Hakimullah-dies-in-Taliban-infighting/articleshow/4872084.cms|title=Baitullah's likely successor Hakimullah dies in Taliban infighting|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftimesofindia.indiatimes.com%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Fpakistan%2FBaitullahs-likely-successor-Hakimullah-dies-in-Taliban-infighting%2Farticleshow%2F4872084.cms&date=2009-08-09|archivedate=9 August 2009|date=9 August 2009|work=[[The Times of India]]}} He had been the TTP's commander in the [[Khyber agency|Khyber]], [[Kurram Agency|Kurram]] and [[Orakzai Agency|Orakzai]] agencies of [[Pakistan]]. He was described as being born about 1979 and a cousin of [[Qari Hussain]]. He was known to be a young and aggressive field commander, who previously served as a driver and was very close to Baitullah Mehsud.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Pakistani Taliban Choose New Chief|url=http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/08/22/world/AP-AS-Pakistan.html|work=The New York Times|date=22 August 2009|accessdate=22 August 2009}} Hakimullah Mehsud maintained ties to [[al-Qaeda]], the Afghan [[Taliban]] and various Pakistani jihadist groups, such as [[Lashkar-e-Taiba]], [[Lashkar-e-Jhangvi]], and [[Jaish-e-Mohammed]]. Reports initially indicated he was fatally wounded on 14 January 2010 by a US drone attack{{cite news |title=Sources: Pakistani Taliban leader is dead |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/02/09/pakistan.meshud.dead/ |publisher=CNN |date=9 February 2010 |accessdate=9 February 2010}}{{Cite news|title=Pakistani Officials Say Taliban Chief Is Dead |work=NPR |date=10 February 2010 |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=123558839&ft=1&f=1004 |accessdate=11 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212084023/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=123558839 |archivedate=12 February 2010 }} although two videos released by the TTP in 2010 and 2011 proved that he survived the attack.{{cite news|first=Carlotta|last=Gall|title=Video Shows U.S. Attack Did Not Kill Top Militant|work=The New York Times|date=3 April 2010|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/03/world/asia/03taliban.html#|accessdate=3 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=e01_1298199749 |title=Taliban release video of killing of Col Imam |publisher=LiveLeak.com |accessdate=17 January 2012}} Mehsud was reported by Pakistani intelligence to have been killed by US [[unmanned combat air vehicle|drone strike]] on 12 January 2012.{{cite news|title=Hakimullah Mehsud reportedly killed in drone strike| date = 14 January 2012|url=http://www.dawn.com/2012/01/15/hakimullah-mehsud-reportedly-killed-in-drone-strike.html|work= Dawn|location=Pakistan|accessdate=15 January 2012}} However, the Pakistani Taliban denied the claim.{{cite web|title=Pakistani Taliban Deny Death of Leader |url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970204555904577162311210518958.html |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=16 January 2012 |date=16 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116051810/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970204555904577162311210518958.html |archivedate=16 January 2012 }} It was later confirmed by the group that he was killed in a drone strike on 1 November 2013.{{cite web|title=Drone strike in Pakistan kills head of Pakistan Taliban|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/11/01/drone-strike-in-pakistan-kills-head-pakistan-taliban-security-sources-say/|work=Fox News|accessdate=1 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=Pakistan Taliban say chief Mehsud killed in drone strike|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-24776363|work=BBC|accessdate=1 November 2013}} ==Early years== Hakimullah was born as Jamshed Mehsud in the region of Kotkai near the town of [[Jandola]] in [[South Waziristan]] in 1979. Mehsud was educated in a small village [[madrassa]] in [[Hangu District (Pakistan)|Hangu District]]. [[Baitullah Mehsud]] also attended the same school but eventually dropped out. ==Militant activity== ===Jihad=== Jamshed Mehsud joined his clansman Baitullah in [[jihad]], initially as his bodyguard and aide. He adopted the nom de guerre Zulfiqar, then later took the name Hakimullah, meaning one who has knowledge. He gained a reputation within the Taliban for his battle skills with the [[AK-47]] and the [[Toyota]] [[pick-up truck]]. One Taliban member told a BBC correspondent that at the time Hakimullah's reputed skills were second only to [[Nek Muhammad Wazir|Nek Mohammad]]. In 2004, he was made a spokesman. He organised a series of raids against US military convoys between the summer of 2007 and the spring of 2008 that forced the closure of the [[Khyber Pass]] six times.{{cite web | url = http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2010/05/the_pakistani_taliba_1.php | title = The Pakistani Taliban's top leaders | accessdate = 8 February 2011 | last = Roggio | first = Bill | date = 7 May 2010 | work = The Long War Journal | publisher = Public Multimedia Inc.}} In 2008, he was given command of the [[Orakzai Agency|Orakzai]], [[Khyber Agency|Khyber]] and [[Kurram district]]s.{{Cite news|title=Hakeemullah cultivates ruthless reputation |newspaper=Dawn |location=Pakistan |date=14 January 2010 |url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/03-hakeemullah-mehsud-cultivates-ruthless-reputation-ss-07 |accessdate=14 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117073133/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/03-hakeemullah-mehsud-cultivates-ruthless-reputation-ss-07 |archivedate=17 January 2010 }} ===Tehrik-e-Taliban leadership === On 22 August 2009, Hakimullah Mehsud was appointed unanimously as the new leader of the Tehrik-e-Taliban by a 42-member shura.{{cite news | last = Khan | first = Hasbanullah | title = Hakeemullah appointed Baitullah's 'successor’ | work = Daily Times | date = 23 August 2009 | url = http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009\08\23\story_23-8-2009_pg1_5 | accessdate = 24 August 2009}} Analysts cited by ''[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|The Daily Times]]'' interpreted the appointment of the 28-year-old commander as a way to admit the death of Baitullah Mehsud although spokesmen for the group continued to vehemently deny his death, instead saying he was ill.{{cite news|author=Bitani, Alamgir|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/homepageCrisis/idUSISL181950._CH_.2400|title=US says evidence Taliban chief dead 'pretty conclusive'|date=9 August 2009|agency=Reuters|accessdate=22 August 2009}} ====Baitullah's successor==== Pakistani news channels reported on 8 August 2009 that Hakimullah Mehsud was killed after shooting erupted between his camp and that of [[Wali-ur-Rehman]] during a [[shura]] to determine the successor to the slain Baitullah Mehsud. Interior Minister [[Rehman Malik]] could not confirm the death only that the fighting had occurred.{{cite news | title = Fighting erupts between Taliban rivals | work = Financial Times | date = 8 August 2009 | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7dd1aa9c-8423-11de-aa5d-00144feabdc0.html | accessdate = 8 August 2009 | quote =Pakistani news channels were carrying unconfirmed reports that Hakimullah Mehsud, one of the movement's most powerful commanders, had been killed at a shura, or council meeting, held to decide who would succeed slain leader Baitullah Mehsud. "The infighting was between Wali-ur-Rehman and Hakimullah Mehsud,” Interior Minister Rehman Malik told Reuters. "We have information that one of them has been killed. Who was killed we will be able to say later after confirming."}} On 10 August, a man claiming to be Hakimullah Mehsud called a Reuters reporter to declare that he and Baitullah were still alive. While the reporter was certain that the call was authentic, Pakistani officials awaited voice analysis results and stated that intercepted phone calls led to the intelligence of Hakimullah's death.{{cite news | last = Shah | first = Pir Zubair |last2=Tavernise |first2=Sabrina | title = U.S. Missile Kills at Least 10 in Pakistan Tribal Area | work = The New York Times | date = 11 August 2009 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/12/world/asia/12pstan.html | accessdate = 11 August 2009}} Wali-ur-Rehman telephoned a Reuters reporter to say that Hakimullah is alive, and would be calling soon, and that the first shura where the shooting supposedly occurred never took place. Hakimullah Mehsud appeared alongside [[suicide bomber]] [[Humam Khalil Abu-Mulal al-Balawi]] in an early January 2010 video that claimed responsibility for the [[Camp Chapman attack]] in retaliation for the death of Baitullah Mehsud.{{Cite news|last=Mehsud |first=Sailab |title=US drone targets Hakimullah Mehsud |newspaper=Dawn |location=Pakistan |publisher=Dawn Media Group |date=15 January 2010 |url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/19-suspected-drone-strikes-in-shaktoai-south-waziristan-casualties-feared-hh-05 |accessdate=14 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106185631/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/19-suspected-drone-strikes-in-shaktoai-south-waziristan-casualties-feared-hh-05 |archivedate=6 January 2011 }}{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8450102.stm | publisher=BBC News | title='CIA bomber' video indicates Taliban's reach | date=9 January 2010 | accessdate=4 May 2010 | first=M Ilyas | last=Khan}} In February 2011, Hakimullah was seen in the execution video of [[Colonel Imam|Sultan Emir Tarar]], better known as Col Imam. Imam was kidnapped in March 2010.{{cite web|author=Express / Online |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/121012/taliban-release-video-of-killing-of-col-imam/ |title=Taliban release video of killing of Col Imam |work=The Express Tribune |accessdate=17 January 2012}} ==Rewards for capture== ===Pakistan bounty=== On 2 November 2009 Pakistani authorities offered a [[Pakistani rupee|Rs]]50 million ([[United States dollars|$]]600,000){{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8337237.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Pakistan offers Taliban bounties | date=2 November 2009 | accessdate=4 May 2010}} reward for information that lead to the capture or killing of Hakimullah Mehsud. They offered the same reward for similar information regarding Wali-ur-Rehman and Qari Hussain and smaller rewards for 16 other TTP militants.{{Cite news | title = Deadly blast rocks Pakistani city | work = Al Jazeera | location = Doha | date = 2 November 2009 | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2009/11/200911274944627440.html | accessdate = 2 November 2009}}{{Cite news|title=Government offers reward for leads on Taliban chiefs |newspaper=Dawn |date=2 November 2009 |url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/07-government-offers-reward-for-leads-on-taliban-chiefs-ha-04 |accessdate=2 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091105014926/http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/07-government-offers-reward-for-leads-on-taliban-chiefs-ha-04 |archivedate=5 November 2009 }} ===United States bounty=== On 1 September 2010 the United States added the militant leader to its list of [[Specially Designated Global Terrorist]]s and the TTP to its list of [[Foreign Terrorist Organization]]s.{{cite press release |title=Designations of Tehrik-E-Taliban Pakistan and Two Senior Leaders |url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2010/09/146545.htm |publisher=U.S. State Department |date=1 September 2010 |accessdate=2 September 2010}} The [[FBI]] posted a reward of [[United States dollars|$]]5 million for information leading to his capture.{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/wanted_terrorists/hakimullah-mehsud/view|title=Hakimullah Mehsud |publisher=FBI |accessdate=9 December 2012}} ==Death== On 1 November 2013, a senior Taliban source confirmed that a US [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]] strike in Pakistan killed Mehsud in the village of [[Dande Darpa Khel]] in [[North Waziristan]]. Dande Darpa Khel was the site of the [[Dande Darpa Khel airstrike]] in 2008. The drone strike also killed two other militants, along with his uncle and cousin.{{cite news|title=Pakistani Taliban confirm leader killed by drone|url=http://bostonherald.com/news_opinion/international/asia/2013/11/pakistani_taliban_confirm_leader_killed_by_drone|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=2 November 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Waziristan}} * [http://www.khyber.org/history/a/waziristan_and_mughal_empire.shtml Waziristan and Mughal empire] * [http://www.khyber.org/history/a/nehru_in_waziristan.shtml Nehru in Waziristan] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150330062703/http://www.khyber.org/images/maps/waziristan.gif Sketch map of Waziristan] * [http://www.khyber.org/history/a/mehsuds_and_wazirs_the_king-ma.shtml Mehsuds and Wazirs, the King-makers in a game of thrones] * [http://www.khyber.org/history/a/lawrence_of_arabia_in_wazirist.shtml Lawrence of Arabia in Waziristan] {{S-start}} {{S-mil}} {{S-bef|before=[[Baitullah Mehsud]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Pakistani Taliban|Leader of Pakistani Taliban]]|years=2009–2013}} {{S-aft|after= [[Maulana Fazlullah]]}} {{end}} {{Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mehsud, Hakimullah}} [[Category:1970s births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:21st-century criminals]] [[Category:Deaths by drone strikes of the Central Intelligence Agency in Pakistan]] [[Category:Individuals designated as terrorists by the United States government]] [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:People from Orakzai Agency]] [[Category:People from South Waziristan]] [[Category:Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan members]]
